title: HTML: A good basis for accessibility
content:
HTML: A good basis for accessibility Previous Overview: Accessibility on the web Next A great deal of web content can be made accessible just by making sure the correct Hypertext Markup Language elements are used for the correct purpose at all times. This article looks in detail at how HTML can be used to ensure maximum accessibility. Prerequisites: Familiarity with HTML , CSS , a basic understanding of accessibility concepts . Learning outcomes: Use semantic HTML, aka "The right element for the right job", because the browser provides so many built-in accessibility hooks. Accessible best practices such as alt text, good link text, form labels, and table row and column headings and scoping. Using simple plain language, steering clear of slang and abbreviations where possible, and providing definitions where it is not possible. The concept and practice of keyboard accessibility. The importance of source order. HTML and accessibility As you learn more about HTML â read more resources, look at more examples, etc. â you'll keep seeing a common theme: the importance of using semantic HTML (sometimes called POSH, or Plain Old Semantic HTML). This means using the correct HTML elements for their intended purpose as much as possible. You might wonder why this is so important. After all, you can use a combination of CSS and JavaScript to make just about any HTML element behave in whatever way you want. For example, a control button to play a video on your site could be marked up like this: html
Play video
But as you'll see in greater detail later on, it makes sense to use the correct element for the job: html Not only do HTML
